title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the trend in the percentage of electricity produced using nuclear energy in Japan between 2000 and 2015, such as any of the following:

· There was a slow decline from 2000 to 2010 and then a rapid decline from 2010 to 2015.

· The percentage of electricity produced using nuclear energy decreased slowly at first and then decreased rapidly.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how France could have used half as much nuclear fuel as the United States when the graph is showing a large difference between the two countries such as the following:

· The graph is comparing/displaying the percentage of electricity produced by source for four different countries. The United States produced a greater total amount of electricity/used more energy than France in the 1990s. Therefore, France did not need as much fuel to produce 70% of their total electricity that was produced by nuclear power plants

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence that supports or refutes the statement that the 1979 partial meltdown at Three Mile Island in the United States had a significant impact on nuclear power generation in the United States after the event, such as any of the following:

· The graph supports this claim because the United States has not experienced a major increase in the percentage of nuclear power used to generate electricity. The meltdown event lead to public concerns about nuclear power and limited new construction.

· The graph refutes this claim because there was not a significant drop in nuclear energy production after 1979. There continued to be a slow but steady increase in nuclear power electricity generation in the United States.

The response makes a claim based on evidence that supports or refutes the statement that the 1979 partial meltdown at Three Mile Island in the United States had a significant impact on nuclear power generation in the United States after the event, such as one of the following:

· The graph supports this claim because the United States has not experienced a major increase in the percentage of nuclear power used to generate electricity. The meltdown event lead to public concerns about nuclear power and limited new construction.

· The graph refutes this claim because there was not a significant drop in nuclear energy production after 1979. There continued to be a slow but steady increase in nuclear power electricity generation in the United States.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe why pairing solar energy with energy from natural gas makes this renewable source a more viable method of electrical production for more United States consumers such as the following:

· Electricity from a natural gas power plant can provide electricity at night, during cloudy days or during the winter when sunlight amount is too limited to generate electricity with solar panels.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one ecological benefit that may result from increasing the amount of vegetation in cities, such as any of the following:

· Provides habitat for species.

· Provides food/nutrients for herbivores/primary consumers/omnivores.

· Increases local plant biodiversity in urban ecosystem.

· Leads to better water quality for plants and animals because there is less surface runoff of water containing pollutants and sediments.

· Leads to better air quality for plants and animals because there is less air pollution from to absorption or negation by vegetation.

The response describes one ecological benefit that may result from increasing the amount of vegetation in cities, such as one of the following:

· Provides habitat for species.

· Provides food/nutrients for herbivores/primary consumers/omnivores.
